details.title: On improved confidence bounds for system reliability
details.standardTitle: On improved confidence bounds for system reliability

p: José Emmanuel Ramírez-Márquez is currently an assistant professor at Stevens Institute of Technology in the Department of Systems Engineering and Engineering Management. Currently, he is focusing his research in areas that include system reliability & quality assurance, uncertainty modeling, advanced heuristics for system reliability analysis, applied probability & statistical models, and applied operations research. He obtained his Ph. D. at Rutgers University in Industrial and Systems Engineering. At Rutgers, he was responsible for conducting research related to the development of analytical methods for improving system reliability performance, and mathematical approaches for computing system reliability when considering multiple performance levels for both systems & components. He received his B.S. degree in Actuarial Science from the UNAM in Mexico City in 1998, and M.S. degrees in Industrial Engineering and Statistics from Rutgers University. He is a member of IIE, and INFORMS.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Syst. Eng. & Eng. Manage., Stevens Inst. of Technol., Hoboken, NJ, USA
authors.name: J.E. Ramirez-Marquez

p: Wei Jiang joined Stevens Institute of Technology as an assistant professor in 2003. Before that, he worked in AT&T labs for four years. He obtained his Ph. D degree from Hong Kong University of Science and Technology in 2000; and B. Sc, and M. Sc degrees from Xi'an Jiaotong University in 1989, and 1992, respectively. His current research interests include statistical methods for quality control, data mining, and enterprise intelligence. He has published many research papers on quality journals including Technometrics, IIE Transactions, Journal of Quality Technology, and others. He is currently serving as a council member for Data Mining cluster; and Secretary/Treasure of Quality, Statistics, and Reliability cluster in INFORMS.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Syst. Eng. & Eng. Manage., Stevens Inst. of Technol., Hoboken, NJ, USA
authors.name: Wei Jiang

details.abstract: In this paper, new bounding strategies are presented to improve confidence interval estimation for system reliability based on component level reliability, and associated uncertainty data. Research efforts have been focused on two interdependent areas: 1) development & improvement of analytical approaches for quantifying the uncertainty associated with the system reliability estimate when data regarding component reliability is available; and 2) based on these analytical approaches, generating statistical inference methods that can be used to make accurate estimations about the reliability of a system. The analytical approach presented relies on a recursive rationale that can be applied to obtain the variance associated with the system reliability estimate, provided the system can be decomposed into a series-parallel configuration. The bounding procedure is independent of parametric assumptions regarding component time to failure, and can be applied whenever component reliability data are available. To assess the validity of the proposed procedure, three test cases have been analyzed. For each case, Monte-Carlo simulation has been used to generate component failure data, based on nominal component reliability values. Based on these simulated data, lower bounds have been constructed, and then compared against nominal system reliability to generate an expected confidence level. The results obtained exhibit a significant improvement in the accuracy of the confidence intervals for the system reliability when compared with existing approximation methods. The procedure described is effective, relatively simple, and widely applicable.

links.abstract: The selection of efficient testing strategies for repairable systems composed of components arranged in series is considered. Two cost models (for perfect and imperfect testing) represent the consequences of possible test realizations. The probability that any particular component is responsible for the failure is derived and used as a basis for the two models. The model for perfect testing is solved exactly. links.abstract: A flexible procedure is described and demonstrated to determine approximate confidence intervals for system reliability when there is uncertainty regarding component reliability information. The approach is robust, and applies to many system-design configurations and component time-to-failure distributions, resulting in few restrictions for the use of these confidence intervals. The methods do not require any parametric assumptions for component reliability or time-to-failure, and allows type-I ...

context.text: Generally, these processes are based on how reliability estimates at the component level impact overall system reliability [7]–[8][9].
By estimating reliability uncertainty, one can identify, measure, and prioritize risks so that economic efforts are used to improve system reliability & safety [8].
Coit [8] provided an approximate confidence interval for any system that can be transformed into a series-parallel configuration.
At the system level, uncertainty associated with the reliability estimate can be associated with the propagation of uncertainty at the component level [7], [8].
Coit [8] has indicated that this propagation depends on system structure, component reliability estimates, and the uncertainty associated with those reliability estimates.

When component test data can be obtained, Coit [8], and Coit & Jin [14] have made important contributions by developing closed form expressions for quantifying the uncertainty associated with the reliability estimate of any system as long as it can be decomposed into a series-parallel configuration.
For a series-parallel system, the variance of the system reliability estimate \$\mathhat{R}_{s-p}(t)\$ is given in Coit [8] as.
To estimate the variance of the reliability estimate, Coit [8] suggests the use of components' reliability estimates to replace \$r_{ij}(t)\$, and \$q_{ij}(t)\$, in the above equation, i.e.
However, when these quantities are replaced by unbiased estimators of \$Var(\mathhat{r}_{ij}(t))\$, the expression developed by Coit [8] is a biased estimator of \$Var(\mathhat{R}_{s-p}(t))\$.

For systems that can be decomposed into a series-parallel transformation, Coit [8] proposed the use of a lognormal distribution to appropriately model system reliability when component reliability information is available.

The results obtained from these examples are enlightening, with respect to the accuracy of the proposed lower confidence bound, because current approaches [7], [8], [11] have a considerable absolute relative error with respect to the selected \$\alpha\$ level.
For each data sample, 100 000 confidence lower bounds (CLB) were constructed with the approach presented by Coit [8], and the two alternatives introduced in this paper.
The first example is a variation of the test system presented by Coit [8].

The results presented in Tables VI & VII illustrate that, when the number of testing units for each components is the same, the accuracy of the bound developed with Alternative 1 provides significant improvement with respect to the \$\alpha\$ level over the results obtained by using the bounding method presented by Coit [8].

As expected, the ARE for both the bound generated by Coit [8], and the bound generated by


Alternative 2, decreases as the number of components increase.
In this sense, for the 10% level, the maximum, and minimum absolute relative errors for the previous method [8] equals approximately 127%, and 31.30% respectively.
